awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Factors of Success in a Community-based, Interactive Engagement Learning Environment: Perspectives from a Minority Serving Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been significant discussion regarding the retention of underrepresented groups in STEM, with the primary focus being on what works to ensure that these individuals successfully transition through each juncture of the STEM pipeline. Additionally, there is a significant body of work characterizing the deficits of students of color who struggle in STEM learning environments, with less focus on their narratives of success. This project seeks to creatively address this gap in the educational research literature by providing empirical data that describes factors that influence minority student success in blended learning environments.  It is envisioned that the work will lead to a better understanding of minority female students as agents of their own success and Spelman's learning environment as one which nurtures and encourages such agency. Few studies of this nature have been conducted at minority serving institutions. 

Based on prior NSF funding, the PIs successfully merged a community-based element with a blended learning environment in Spelman's general and organic chemistry courses. In the proposed work, they plan to document what is occurring in this learning environment with respect to engagement (metacognitive, cognitive, behavioral, and relational) and affective traits that comprise a student's sense of agency (motivation, efficacy, effort, and mindset). The PIs have constructed a solid well-conceived theoretical framework for their investigations. They are taking three different perspectives: agency, metacognition, and "Community of Inquiry" (CoI) and using them to examine the nature of the self-regulated learning exhibited by the students. Using a mixed methods approach to get information on "narratives of success" within the environment, the project entails the extraction of data from a well-established and controlled setting at Spelman College. The project has the potential to complement efforts around the country to create curricula and learning environments that transform students, particularly minority women, into effective learners.

inst.inst_name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

por.por_cntn:
One of the goals of this grant was to characterize students' cognitive, relational, and behavioral engagement in flipped or blended learning environment. Group discussions are widely used in blended learning courses. Although, there is evidence that group activities may benefit student learning there is little known about how students interact during these activities and what components lead to improved learning. We investigated students' engagement and dialogue during a group quiz activity that was embedded in the blended learning environment. Through a qualitative analysis of students' dialogue via the Interactive-Constructive-Active-Passive (ICAP) framework, we were able to have a deeper insight into student interaction and dialogue during group discussions. Within the ICAP framework, interactive dialogue produces the highest level of learning, followed by constructive, active, and then passive at the lowest.

It was clear from our study that learning from group discussions are not guaranteed and that it is dependent on the quality of the group discussion. Our analysis has shown that the level of cognitive engagement (ICAP) of students varies widely across group discussion activities. As such, the impact on student learning through group activities also varies. A key finding was that the highest level of cognitive engagement occurred when the discussion or quiz prompt was at least a Marzano level 3 (Analysis). Level 3 prompts ask students to compare, contrast and organize information. These prompts allow students to begin developing arguments and dialogue that leads to co-construction of knowledge and ultimately deeper learning among group members. Such prompts generated more interactive and constructive elements in students' discussions. Our results imply that instructors need to provide prompts and guidance within the prepared activity that catalyzes and normalizes behaviors such as asking other students questions, prompting explanations, and giving all students an opportunity to speak. 

Often, group work is assessed by their final answer. However, much is missed about the group's process if only the final answer is considered. To this end, this work points to the importance of classroom observation. That is, instructors and researchers can gain invaluable insights into improving discussion prompts and group composition through occasional classroom observation.

This work supported the training of three graduate students in qualitative and quantitative research methods. Also, the insights gained from this study in chemistry can be applied to similar learning environments across STEM disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Suazette R Mooring
